Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: A Framework for Assessing the Impact of Extreme Heat and Drought on Urban Energy Production and Consumption

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration: This research will produce novel, rigorous and integrative methods that will contribute to society's capacity for effectively managing city-scale electricity systems during periods of extreme heat and drought. The modern electric grid, which includes both electricity consumers and producers, faces significant challenges and uncertainties, including increased frequency and intensity of heat waves and droughts. Concurrently, the processes underlying electricity production and consumption are becoming more complex, due in part to advances in electric grid-connected technologies and the demand-side management programs that control them. This research will improve knowledge of city-specific future extreme heat and drought scenarios, as well as quantification of the impact of extreme events under these scenarios on a city's electricity consumption and production. Findings from this research have the potential to significantly impact the way cities and electric utility operators manage electric grids under extreme heat and drought conditions.<br/><br/>This project addresses vital links between climate modeling, consumption and production, and seeks to contribute to the following scientific advancements: 1) development of effective methods for generating refined future extreme heat and drought scenarios utilizing disparate sources of data of varying fidelity, such as historical observations; 2) development of a flexible electricity consumption model integrated with demand-side management strategies using bottom-up energy and demand modeling methods; 3) development of a data-driven stochastic optimization method for robust power-generation decision strategies that considers various sources of uncertainty, including weather and the consumption and production of electricity.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Changing climate conditions and resulting extreme weather conditions threaten to impact electric grid infrastructure and the people that rely on this infrastructure, particularly in cities where significant portions of the U.S. population reside. There is a need to better understand and predict how these extreme weather events impact cities’ energy needs, both spatially and temporally. The main focus of this project was to develop methods that assess the impact of current and future projected extreme weather events on city-scale energy use and demands. More specifically this project’s results include, for city weather conditions, improved modeling of spatially and temporally varying extreme weather (extreme heat) conditions in urban locations, and improved prediction of extreme heat scenarios under future climate projections. For city-level energy modeling and prediction of energy use, this research project’s results include several methods for city-scale energy modeling to reduce the amount of data and time needed to develop and validate energy use prediction models for a large number of buildings. The results of this project help to support understanding and ability to predict city-level energy consumption with a limited number of available inputs, combined with extreme weather event prediction in future climates. This provides improved ability to support understanding the future electric grid’s reliability under extreme weather conditions, to support city-scale decision making.
